docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Bloomberg is supposed to enter the race for mayor of New York today, not in the flesh but via a barrage of TV commercials. There is also a Web site, where you can dial up www.mikeformayor.org and find a photo and biography. (''The former Eagle Scout's passion for helping others comes from his strong belief that those who are fortunate have an obligation . . .'') Voters' first impression of the campaign is going to be that the city has a hologram running for chief executive.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column on media magnate Michael Bloomberg, who plans to enter New York City's mayoral race on Republican ticket (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge declared a mistrial today in the case of a midwife charged with the death of a baby she delivered in a couple's suburban Chicago home. After five days of deliberation, the jury acquitted the midwife, Yvonne Cryns, of involuntary manslaughter of an unborn child. But the jurors deadlocked on another involuntary-manslaughter charge, leading the judge to declare the mistrial.

headline.main: Manslaughter Charges Against Lay Midwife Lead to Mistrial

docs.abstract: Chicago Circuit Court Judge James Booras declares mistrial in case of Yvonne Cryns, midwife charged in death of baby she delivered in couple's suburban Chicago home after jury found her guilty on one involuntary manslaughter charge but deadlocked on another; prosecutors plan retrial; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BY the time all the Tony Awards have been distributed at Radio City Music Hall tonight, it is possible that four of the six actors in August Wilson's ''King Hedley II'' will have hurried to the stage. Brian Stokes Mitchell, Leslie Uggams, Charles Brown and Viola Davis have been nominated for their portrayals of characters trying to make their constricted lives amount to something in Pittsburgh's hardscrabble Hill District during the 1980's. In their performances the four players get the opportunity to deliver the kind of attention-grabbing monologues that are Mr. Wilson's signature: lengthy outbursts full of passion. ''August does epic scope with the simplest arrangement of words,'' Mr. Brown is saying when Ms. Uggams and Ms. Davis crowded into his narrow dressing-room in the Virginia Theater one day last month. They had gathered to sort out what makes an August Wilson tragi-comedy so rewarding -- in more ways than one -- for actors. ''There are no convoluted sentences in August's heart-rending speeches -- they are absolutely mind-altering,'' Mr. Brown said. He plays Elmore, an aging con artist trying to change his slippery habits but finding them too deep-seated to expunge easily.

headline.main: Acting 'King Hedley II': 'It Just Makes You Soar'

docs.abstract: Tony-nominees Leslie Uggams, Charles Brown and Viola Davis comment on performing in August Wilson play King Hedley II; actor Brian Stokes Mitchell also received nomination; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hal Sutton, a veteran P.G.A. Tour player, wondered aloud the other day whether Casey Martin's United States Supreme Court victory last Tuesday would spur other golfers to get a golf cart, too. Any number of players have bad backs, he observed, himself included. Sutton's reaction zeroed in on the court's major conclusion in rendering its decision: walking is not fundamental to professional tournament play, even though through centuries it has been taken for granted as an integral part of the game. If walking is not fundamental, and the physically disabled are entitled to a cart as a ''reasonable accommodation'' to their disability, then who besides Casey Martin qualifies?

headline.main: Martin Case Raises Issues On Its Impact

docs.abstract: Article comments on Supreme Court decision that found Casey Martin can use golf cart in tournament play; decision is specific, allowing only those with permanent disability to use cart, likely disqualifying those with bad back or other less serious afflictions; says it is too soon to forecast if there will be wide-ranging impact; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cindy Shipper rested comfortably with her newborn son, Tzvi, while his twin sister, Sarah, napped in a nearby nursery. Soon Mrs. Shipper would enjoy a fine meal, then fall off to sleep in her tastefully decorated room, complete with freshly cut flowers. As well behaved as her three other children -- ages 7, 5 and 3 -- are, there is little likelihood that Mrs. Shipper, who had given birth to the twins just days ago, would have this kind of a chance to recuperate from childbirth at her home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
docs.abstract: Article describes luxury amenities and care provided to new mothers and newborn babies from Hasidic Jewish community, discharged quickly by hospitals, at 36-bed post-partum center at Leisure Chateau nursing home in Lakewood, NJ; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: We are all living now in Sandra Day O'Connor's America. Take almost any of the most divisive questions of American life, and Justice O'Connor either has decided it or is about to decide it on our behalf. The Supreme Court may tell us soon whether affirmative action in public universities is permissible, and if it does, O'Connor is likely to cast the deciding vote. The court is divided about school vouchers too; O'Connor's views will probably tip the scales. Voting districts drawn for the benefit of minorities have to be submitted for O'Connor's approval and stand or fall on whether she finds their shapes bizarre. Roe v. Wade has been tailored according to O'Connor's specifications, and judges and legislators have to scrutinize all abortion restrictions in an effort to predict whether O'Connor might consider them an ''undue burden'' on the right to choose. And in December O'Connor helped to decide the presidential election, joining the 5-4 vote to stop the Florida recount and delivering the White House to George W. Bush.
docs.abstract: Jeffrey Rosen article on Sandra Day O'Connor as justice who decides which way Supreme Court goes in many major cases and as court's lead champion of federalism: the return of power from federal government to states; says she takes distinctive approach to role as swing vote, joining majority and then writing concurring opinion that drain her colleagues' reasoning of its more general implications and preserve her ability to change her mind in future; says she has recently joined conservative colleagues on court in determination to reserve for themselves exclusive authority to decide what counts as illegal and impermissible in America; says her highhanded attitude toward Congress, state courts and Aemrican people reached its height in Bush v Gore, decision that typifies her personalized jurisprudence; notes speculation that O'Connor might be court's next chief justice and suggests that her vision of court's role in American life may not really be appropriate today; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jurors in a suburban Chicago courtroom reported that they were deadlocked in the trial of a midwife charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of a baby boy during a home delivery last August. The judge, James Booras, told the jurors to continue deliberating. Prosecutors said that the defendant, Yvonne Cryns, a lay midwife, took too long to call for help in a birth she knew was risky because of the baby's feet-first position and that the way she twisted the baby contributed to his death. Pam Belluck (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Deadlock In Midwife's Trial

docs.abstract: Jurors in suburban Chicago courtroom say they are deadlocked in trial of Yvonne Cryns, midwife charged with involuntary manslaugher in death of baby during home delivery last August; judge orders jurors to continue deliberating; prosecutors say Cryns took too long to call for help in birth she knew to be risky; photo (S)
